SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional bloating. He attributes these symptoms to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. He has been experiencing these symptoms for about five weeks. Mr. Brian also reports a slight cough and occasional chest cramps that resolve within an hour. He denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

Mr. Brian has been monitoring his blood pressure at home and reports that it has been well controlled. He has struggled with his diet recently due to home renovations, which has led to eating out more frequently and consuming less healthy food options.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Positive occasional chest cramps. No chest pain.
• Respiratory: Positive slight cough. No shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Positive bloating. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor daily weight and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure well controlled at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity. No calf pain.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid, but overall alignment is proper.

IMPRESSION

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin, 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used icy heat, but these did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He plans to improve his eating habits.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, resolved on Sunday afternoon.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating suboptimal control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee pain and no further workup is needed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He states that his depression is well managed and maintained.

Regarding his hypertension, he admits to occasionally forgetting to take his Norvasc on weekends but has been generally compliant with the medication. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion during his daily 4-5 mile runs, especially in humid conditions.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high pollen season.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Refill Prozac prescription.

Prior Lobectomy.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is exercising regularly and has no significant respiratory issues.
• Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on Norvasc.
• Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for further evaluation. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient referred by Diane Nelson for long-standing iron deficiency anemia. The patient reports being anemic since the age of 13. She recently attempted to donate blood in December and was informed of her anemia. She has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. The patient also reports increased anxiety and depression.

The patient had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with no polyps found. She denies having a pacemaker, defibrillator, sleep apnea, or using oxygen at night. She drinks alcohol once or twice a year. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25mg tablets twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy (1996).

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: once or twice a year.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25mg tablets (twice daily).
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient appears well-nourished and in no acute distress.
Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
2. Continue ferrous sulfate 25mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for better absorption for the next 8-12 weeks.
3. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate after 12 weeks.
4. Referral to hematologist (Dr. Flores) for further evaluation and management.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy. Schedule appointment with hematologist Dr. Flores. Follow bowel prep instructions for colonoscopy. Call clinic with any additional concerns or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward, a 52-year-old male, presents to the clinic for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for headaches included brain MRI and serology, which incidentally discovered the pituitary lesion. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrated a low TSH, with all other results normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 revealed a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. No other abnormalities were noted.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a gradual onset and worsening severity over the past three months. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. No other symptoms were reported, such as fever, neck stiffness, numbness, or weakness.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None

Family
Unknown (adopted)

Social
Married for 25 years, computer programmer, non-smoker, non-drinker, no recreational drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS
Imaging

MRI brain with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery for excision and decompression of the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.

End of note.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient reports that the chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and worsened with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient went to the ER, where she had a normal cardiac workup, including EKG and blood tests. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient's symptoms resolved approximately three days after her ER visit and have not recurred since then.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Esophagitis (suspected).

Surgical
Cholecystectomy (gall bladder removal).

SOCIAL HISTORY

No significant social history provided.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history of GI problems.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None provided.

ALLERGIES

None provided.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for weight loss, abdominal pain, and bowel movement issues.
Positive for chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, which have since resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. Otherwise, the exam is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. The patient was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the symptoms, which may have contributed to her condition.

PLAN

1. Discussed the option of EGD (upper endoscopy) versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, weighing 4 pounds and 8 ounces. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned potential kidney issues associated with her syndrome.

The patient has approximately 8-10 wet diapers in a 24-hour period. She drinks a combination of pea protein milk, water, and occasionally water with a small amount of juice.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Smith-Magenis Syndrome, prematurity, feeding difficulties, reflux, developmental delays.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, at risk for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
2. If the ultrasound results are normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.
3. If the ultrasound results are abnormal, determine the next steps and schedule a follow-up appointment at the Town Center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. The nurse will provide paperwork and instructions for the ultrasound. The doctor will call with the results and discuss any necessary next steps.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms. She reports that her right wrist started to hurt severely and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. The patient denies any previous injuries to this arm. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not mentioned.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Lower extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
Upper extremities: Normal range of movement in left arm, pain and limited movement in right wrist. Tenderness on palpation, swelling, and ecchymosis present in right wrist. Bony crepitus noted.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace for her right wrist. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be placed in a brace for six weeks and will attend physical therapy three times per week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess the patient's progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan and attend all scheduled appointments. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office for further evaluation.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, on 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain with flexion and extension.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: not provided
Respiration: not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema.
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation over the medial aspect of the knee. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. These reveal no evidence of any fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient reports slipping and falling, causing pain and swelling in the right knee.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of his diagnosis and x-ray results. I advised him to avoid putting pressure on the knee and to elevate it when possible.
- Medical Treatment: He will take ibuprofen 800 mg, twice daily to reduce pain and inflammation. He will also wear a knee brace for support and ice the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times daily.

2. Hypertension
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit. He has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of a low-sodium diet and the need for better dietary control.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril. Referral to nutrition for dietary management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant male patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The onset of her pain is occasional, less than once a day, and occurs when walking. The patient describes the pain as internal and involving the whole kneecap. She denies hearing or feeling a pop in her knee and cannot recall any specific injury to the knee. The pain does not last long and does not require any pain medications. The patient is concerned about her knee giving out during an upcoming trip that involves walking and line dancing.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports taking blood pressure medications regularly.

Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugars, taking metformin regularly.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from nursing staff, family, and friends.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports minimal cough and sore throat, mild fatigue, no nausea or vomiting.
Respiratory: Dry cough, no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: No difficulty swallowing, decreased appetite.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen of cisplatin and etoposide, and current dose of radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor response and potential for surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve cough and shortness of breath.

3. Painful swallowing and sore throat.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow, to be used four times a day, to help with pain relief and improve ability to eat and drink.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal lab work - low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger. No recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. Recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works at a family-owned donut shop. Recently traveled to Zambia.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness.

VITALS

All vitals within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a common immunodeficiency with slightly lower than normal IgA levels. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without complications. Some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections, but this does not seem to be the case for this patient.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check other antibody levels.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Informed patient about the IgA deficiency and advised them to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. Instructed patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed by primary care physician. Encourage patient to maintain a healthy diet and monitor blood sugar levels.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He reports that the pain is located on the inside of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been keeping him up at night. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

The patient has recently been engaging in pottery and ceramics, which he believes may have contributed to the development of his elbow pain.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient is involved in pottery and ceramics.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is also instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to assess the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during exertion.
Genitourinary: Denies urinary incontinence.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes and goes. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain with minimal relief. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a history of kidney stones and his father also had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for any breakthrough pain.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for further analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient should contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister with stinging pain but has since progressed to a necrotic wound with a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with some improvement in symptoms but has recently noticed blackening around the wound, calf cramping, and a red streak along the inside of his calf muscle. He also reports difficulty catching his breath and a cough in the last two days. His blood sugars have been trending higher in the last two weeks, with some readings in the 300-400 range.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His last A1C was 6.7.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports being active and enjoying hiking with his wife.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports cough and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No headaches or numbness/tingling in feet.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Not provided
RESPIRATORY: Not provided
NECK: Not provided
MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Vascular exam shows bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, but no palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses (present via Doppler). No pain on palpation of the affected wound area.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed with the patient the need for further evaluation and treatment of his non-healing right foot ulcer. I will order a test to check blood supply for the wound and perform a debridement in the office today. We will also obtain a culture and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on the results. The patient will be closely monitored for the redness moving up his leg and the swelling and pain in his calf. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in 7 days. The patient is advised to follow up with his endocrinologist to ensure proper management of his diabetes and maintain his hemoglobin A1C below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports a tick bite on the right knee, which occurred over a week ago. The area is warm and burning. No fever or chills reported. Patient has a history of spending time outdoors, including hunting.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg once daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.
Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.
Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.
Cardiovascular: Denies dizziness.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a tick bite on the right knee, erythema, edema, and bull's-eye rash.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm Lyme disease.
- Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently taking Lisinopril.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg once daily.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of diabetes and is currently taking Metformin.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
